column1: Workload is spread over the whole team (one team member is often Xtimes more productive than the others...
but nevertheless, here is a track record that everyone is contributing a lot)
Number of commits: by different people
Docs: doco generated, format not ugly
Docs: what: point descriptions of each class/function (in isolation)
Docs: how: for common use cases X,Y,Z mini-tutorials showing worked examples on how to do X,Y,Z
Docs: why: docs tell a story, motivate the whole thing, deliver a punchline that makes you want to rush out and use the thing
Docs: short video, animated, hosted on your repo. That convinces people why they want to work on your code.

column3: config files iin GH showing this checker's config
dozens of tests and all methods are tested.

column1: The files http://contributing.md/ lists coding standards and lots of tips on how to extend the system without screwing things up
column3: the http://contributing.md file has tips to extend the system without breaking it.

column1: Issues are discussed before they are closed
column3: theyâ€™re discussed under the issues tab

column1: Test cases: a large proportion of the issues related to handling failing cases.
column3: If a test case fails, open an issue and fix it but majority are not issues related failing testcase.

column1: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools: everyone can get to all tools and files
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. config files in the repo, updated by lots of different people)
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. tutor can ask anyone to share screen, they demonstrate the system running on their computer)
Evidence that the members of the team are working across multiple places in the code base
column3: In the code files multiple contributors to different parts of the project
(hard to see in short projects) project members are committing often enough so that everyone can get your work
